metadata_frame: This question asks you to provide dialogue for a character in a book. The book in this case is a historical novel published in 1903 by William O. Stoddard, a American writer born in 1835.
main_question:
The character in question here is Lee Bowie, who is described this way in the book:
"He was tall for his age, if he were not quite seventeen, and he had a pair of dark, brilliant eyes, like those of a young hawk. They were dancing with excitement at this moment, and his sun-browned face was flushed as he stepped quickly forward.", "the handsome face under it was white with anger, and his teeth were hard set.", "his hawk-like eyes met the piercing gaze of the general without a quiver", "he was a gay-looking young patriot.", "Lee Bowie was rigged after a fashion to attract the attention of any observer, and his abundant black hair had not been cropped for many a long day.", "Lee's hawk eyes were flashing instantly."

At one moment in the book, Lee Bowie watches General Washington and remarks on the ongoing siege work at Yorktown. Write a short passage of dialogue (1-3 sentences) that Lee Bowie might speak in this situation:
answer_strings: General Washington himself! He is going somewhere. I wish I knew where he is going.
I want to see my brothers, and if there is going to be a battle, I want to carry a musket.
Did you, my brave fellow? Well, I declare! If you are not the very man that hoisted me over the parapet!
General, Yorktowns siege lines tighten like a hawks talons; the earth trembles under our resolve.
passage:
Perhaps his head was not now so full as it had been, for certainly a great deal had gone out of it, and it had done a tremendous amount of unloading, here and there, but his heart was filling up so that it was actually swelling. There was a blur, too, before his eyes, and he hardly knew what was going on around him. That is, he was soon aware that two pairs of strong arms went around him, one after the other, and that he was enthusiastically welcomed by a couple of bronzed and bearded men in rusty uniforms which might never have been as brilliant as was his own. Then he was led into a tent, and only those two men were with him. It was a grand time for 

Lee, and all the reporting he had performed for General Washington or anybody else was as nothing compared to the account which he had to give of himself and his doings during the many long months since the Bowie brothers had looked each other in the face. It was a long, long talk, and it was a late hour in the night when the major and the captain, for such they were, went away to their rest and their soldier duties so that their newly found, or rather rediscovered, brother could lie down upon his French blanket and go to sleep. He did so with a curious idea floating around in his mind that it would be almost beyond belief, next morning, to wake up with-
out any help from the British drum-taps and not have to go out and feed and curry the horses of the king's cavalry. As for them, they had been his companions so long that even while his eyes were closing he drowsily raised his head and listened to hear if there were possibly any disturbance among them. He slept soundly and long, but it was no drum-beat that awakened him. It was the roar of a heavy gun, for Washington now knew what was to be the next movement of Lord Cornwallis, and he had ordered a forward movement which was intended to encourage his lordship in retiring within his inner line of entrenchments. CHAPTER XVIII  

Ir was a dark night, and it appeared to be especially gloomy over the wide, unoccupied space between the British lines and the camps of the American army before Yorktown. Among these there were camp-fires burning, and there were lanterns moving here and there. One of these lanterns passed by the huts and tents of the Maryland line at about half-past seven o'clock, and it found Lee Bowie standing in front of a tent, leaning upon his beautiful new musket. He was not there on duty, however, and it was not the mere light of the lantern which gave him such a start. "General Washington himself!" he exclaimed. “He is going somewhere. I wish I knew where he is going." The general was not alone, for several officers and an escort of riflemen were with him, and none of these said a word to Lee when he shouldered his musket and fell into the hindmost rank as if he belonged there. All were on foot, and Lee's curiosity grew stronger 213
and stronger as they marched on in silence away beyond the spot where he had escaped so remarkably from Captain Cary's scouting party. Then he saw the general himself take the lantern and hold it up for a moment, looking at something. "Hullo!" said Lee. "They are digging like mad! They are throwing up a breastwork. It looks like a long one." So it did, for as the general turned and walked slowly onward, pausing now and then to speak to the men and their officers, Lee discovered that these new works were to extend along the entire front, about two miles, for the siege of Yorktown had begun in earnest and the French and American soldier laborers were constructing the first (6 parallel" of the approaches.

main_question:
The character in question here is Governor Jefferson, who is described this way in the book:
"An angry, red flush was creeping over the face of Governor Jefferson when he exclaimed"

At one moment in the book, Governor Jefferson speaks to Lee Bowie, giving him instructions and warnings while Lee responds. Write a short passage of dialogue (1-3 sentences) that Governor Jefferson might speak in this situation:
answer_strings: Lee Bowie, you are a brave fellow. I mean to be over there at Manchester, on the other side of the James, at about ten oclock to-morrow. Get across as soon as you have learned all you can, but you may not be able to do that the first day.

I wish I had a thousand riflemen as full of pluck as she is. If I had, Id teach Benedict Arnold a lesson. As it is, I have hardly more than two hundred militia. The rest have delayed turning out until its too late.

My dear friend, take another view of the situation. Think! If our population increases at the rate of ten per cent per annum, we must have fifty per cent more men than when the war began. For every man killed in battle or dying in these wretched camps, there are dozens coming of military age all over the land.
Governor Jefferson: Lee, keep the militia ready until dusk, or the rebels will take the town. I will not tolerate disobedience—if you fail, you answer to the state.
passage:
Considerable numbers, indeed, went out into the country northward on foot, and Jefferson advised all able-bodied men to do it at once. There were some who had families and refused to leave them. There were old and feeble folk and women and children, and all who were sick were compelled to keep to their unprotected beds while they waited to learn what the hands of the enemy would do for the helpless capital of the old Virginia Dominion. Governor Jefferson himself was now on horseback, dashing hither and thither at a rate which before night about killed the good animal which carried him. He succeeded in doing to the last inch whatever there was to be done, and there had been one point in his favor. For some inscrutable reason, General Arnold had made a blunder the previous day. Instead of pushing on up the river and saving every possible mile of distance before going ashore, he had landed, as Tom Evans reported, at 

Westover, twenty-five miles below his destination. This was on the 3d of January, and he had been able to advance only a dozen miles or so before night. He went into camp with his whole force, and, although he set out bright and early on the morning of the 4th, anything like 2
a surprise was now out of the question. The vigorous 

Virginia governor, standing there in the road, had but been waiting for precisely the news which Tom Evans brought him, and such things as State papers and records were already far away at Charlottesville or elsewhere. Toward night the governor took a fresh horse in place of the one he had used up, and galloped off to join his family at Tuckahoe, and to send it yet farther into the interior. The last man to whom he spoke, when he mounted his horse to go, was only a boy, after all. "Lee Bowie," said the author of the Declaration," you are a brave fellow. I mean to be over there at Manchester, on the other side of the James, at about ten o'clock to-morrow. Get across as soon as you have learned all you can, but you may not be able to do that the first day. Wait!" "Yes, sir," replied Lee. "I'll wait and watch till 

I've something that's worth while, but if you don't see me again pretty soon, you may just know they've made an end of me- 99 "Or made a prisoner of you," interrupted the governor, "and that's almost as bad, sometimes. Watch and lie still! Good-by!" He struck in his spurs at that moment and his horse sprang swiftly away. "Spy? Spy?" exclaimed Lee Bowie, looking after
NO ARMY 

11 him. "No, I ain't even so much as a scout. I'm only a fellow that stayed behind in Richmond because he wanted to see the British march in. I'd like to watch 'em, though, along a rifle-barrel, resting across a fence for a good aim." CHAPTER II  

(6 THE poor fellows are worn out! I was afraid of this. Oh, how sorry I am! I wish I could do something for them. They have endured heroically." A tall, noble-looking man, in the buff-and-blue uniform of the Continental army, stood near a window with an open letter in his hand. He raised the letter and appeared to be reading it over slowly from end to end. Then he turned and gazed thoughtfully out of the window. It was a cold and dreary midwinter landscape. There was more snow to be seen than in the neighborhood of Richmond, but the scenery was as desolate and the trees were as leafless.

main_question:
The character in question here is General Arnold, who is described this way in the book:
"He is a wonderfully energetic officer", "General Arnold rode off with a face which acknowledged for him that he did not like being a subordinate.", "man in elegant attire", "General Arnold, in his shirt-sleeves, his epauletted coat thrown off on account of the heat, was striding up and down in his room at the headquarters on the evening of the 19th of May."

At one moment in the book, Arnold confronts Lee Bowie, demanding he bring the young man to him. Write a short passage of dialogue (1-3 sentences) that General Arnold might speak in this situation:
answer_strings: Bring the young wolf to me. Ill see what there is in him.
Thats it, is it? You are a rebel soldier, and you came up from Greenes army.
Lee, bring the young man here at once. I will not tolerate delay.
passage:
Moreover, Arnold had by some means been informed that the governor, whom he had so much hoped to capture, was at this hour at Manchester, on the opposite bank of the James, as he had promised Lee Bowie, and several of the citizens had been compelled to carry to him a message. It was somewhat in the nature of a flag of truce, and it proposed a kind of plunderer's bargain. Arnold offered to spare the town all injury if his vessels of all sorts might be permitted to come up the river unhindered, to take on board cargoes of the abundant tobacco which the marauders had found in the warehouses in and about Richmond. The offer was, of course, to be indignantly rejected. While no confidence whatever could be given to any such promise, the proposal itself informed the governor of Arnold's military weakness, and that he did not intend to attempt a permanent occupation. At the same time, he had no means of inflicting harm upon a few small craft which had already reached the Richmond wharves. The flag of truce, with its buccaneering bargain, was still on its way when Lee Bowie quietly sauntered away from Mrs. Betty Randolph's gate with a mental deter-
mination to be guided by the old woman's caustic admonitions. While the greater part of the population had prudently decided to keep indoors, a considerable number, mostly boys of various sizes, were out for a look at the British. Neither officers nor soldiers were paying them any attention, for they were not plunder, nor was there any apparent military danger in them. It would not, however, have required a very sharp pair of eyes to have detected a difference between the manner and bearing of Lee Bowie and the others, as he went around from place to place and took swift notes of every horse and gun and soldier. There was an alertness, a keen flash of the eye, a compression of the lips, and an air of being on important business which was not at all in accord with Mrs. Randolph's instructions. Nobody had as yet spoken to him, but every inch of him betrayed the fact that he was a young patriot wishing that he had a gun with which to shoot this entire invasion of Virginia by Great Britain. 3
CHAPTER III  

"THERE! The villains are setting the buildings on fire. They are breaking into the houses. They are plundering everywhere. It's time for me to go back to Mrs. 

Randolph's. I can't do any more just now." It was only too true. Arnold's embassy had gone and had returned, and the reply he had received had stirred up all the vindictive spirit within him. It had also appeared to tell him that the governor must have more forces at hand or shortly to arrive. It might be, therefore, that his expedition was in danger of speedy interruption, and that it would be well for him to do his remaining work quickly. It was about the middle of the afternoon and Lee Bowie had almost reached his place of intended refuge, when he suddenly felt a strong hand on his shoulder and heard a loud, angry voice commanding: "Bring the young wolf to me. I'll see what there is in him." 26
In a moment more he was standing in front of a man of not more than medium stature, broad shouldered, strongly built, with an aquiline nose and fiercely piercing eyes. His face seemed to express a superabundance of fiery energy, pride, courage. He was just the man to have done all the daring deeds, with perhaps one sad exception of insanity, which had made up the brilliant but erratic record of General Benedict Arnold. "Now, you young rascal, who are you? This youngster here says you are not a Richmond boy. You came from the South. Out with it!" Hard held by a soldier who stood near the general was a little chap of not more than ten who at this moment broke in with: "No, thir. He ith one of our men. He came with 'patches to the gov'nor. I'd like to thee him thoot you dead!"

At one moment in the book, Arnold delivers papers to General Philips, gives orders, and later vents his frustration about being superseded. Write a short passage of dialogue (1-3 sentences) that General Arnold might speak in this situation:
answer_strings: This contains the correspondence I mentioned, and some other things of varied importance. Everything about the post is in complete readiness for your own further orders.
I think I would wish it myself. I will only say now that I have important correspondence to turn over at once.
No, I dont at all like the look of things. We must drive Steubens rebels back into the interior at once, and we must keep the road from the South open for Lord Cornwallis.

passage:
On arriving at the old man-
BURNING UP 

99 sion which had been turned into headquarters, they went at once into what might be called its business room, formerly its parlor, attended by a number of staff officers and several naval gentlemen of distinction. Hardly had they entered the room, however, and as if it were his first duty, under the circumstances, Arnold delivered to General Philips a not very large packet of papers, remarking: "This contains the correspondence I mentioned, and some other things of varied importance. Everything about the post is in complete readiness for your own further orders." "General Arnold," he responded with a somewhat peculiar dignity of manner, "please go on giving your own orders for the present. I will take these papers to my room now, for I wish to compare them with others that 

I already have. I will see you again at the dinner-table." "Certainly, general," exclaimed Arnold. "I will show you your room." Out they went together, unattended by others, and in three minutes more Arnold returned alone, to say to the company, which now made the "business room" almost crowded and also noisy with all sorts of conversation: "Gentlemen, I am compelled to repeat, after our distinguished commander, that I will see you all again at the dinner-table. That will suit you, undoubtedly, and 

I have also his additional instructions." Without another word, he stepped quickly out of the room, and they were left to their own devices, or rather to the hospitable care of his staff and of a fast-arriving swarm of the officers of the Portsmouth force. General Philips was now alone in the chamber which had been provided for him, and he was hastily examining the packet of correspondence. He was apparently under the pressure of some strong anxiety, the cause of which he did not explain aloud. General Arnold was also alone, in another room, and he was standing with his back against the mantel of its fireplace, but he was not examining anything; that is, not anything in writing or that would have been visible to anybody else. 66 

It has come!" he said, in a low, husky tone. "I am superseded. This is one more fruit of the jealousy that 

I have seen from the beginning. It is perfectly clear to me. After all I have done, they do not consider me one of themselves. They can not really distrust me, for my very life is at stake. I am the only officer in the king's forces who can not permit himself to be taken prisoner. An original Tory might be a safe prisoner of war, but I would not. And now, why am I deprived of an independent command and of an opportunity to distinguish myself and prove my loyalty? He left his place at the mantel and began to stride rapidly up and down the room. It was evident that some- 

---
BURNING UP 

101 thing or other had stung him deeply, but it ought not to have been the mere arrival of General Philips. No rightminded military man should have felt hurt at finding himself outranked by his superior officer. Neither could the

British army authorities be expected to regulate their appointments to duty with reference to any one man's personal ambition. Possibly, therefore, Arnold's present fit of dissatisfaction was affording a kind of pinhole through which might be seen one of the weaknesses which had led him into his awkward position. "Superseded!" he again exclaimed. "Just as I had completed my plans. Oh, what could I not have done with these reenforcements! And now Philips will get the credit of whatever successes are to follow. Well, at all events, I have blistered the Virginians, and that is something. As soon as I can, I must and will have a force at my own disposal. What I mean to do is to strike New England harder than I have the Old Dominion. I want to burn out that nest of rebel privateers at New London. That would be a blow at the rebellion that it would stagger under. Then I'd like to push on up the river and burn New Haven.
